narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I found the course very general later in the semester. I think the course needs to be focused on Industrial engineering concept, and policy and sustainability issues were more than I expected. I thought it will be a specialized course in Industrial ecology, but It was not.
na
It will be better if we can use real data to practice MFA before doing our research. We might need more exercise.

The course is very superficial. I wish we would have actually learned to do industrial ecology. Ways of doing this would be by making the problem sets challenging. Also, problem sets should be used as a way to prepare student for their project. Otherwise, the project is mostly an improvisation which is very frustrating to students.
The group projects and the trips that went along with those projects were very helpful.

Workload heavy due to final project though I wouldn't reduce the workload. It is important to give more bounded projects (i.e. projects that can be completed within the semester. The projects should be assigned with clear boundaries, it should not be up to the students to set those boundaries since they are unfamiliar with the topic/project.

As always, I appreciate the hands-on approach of the project component of the course, and I think the principles of Industrial Ecology are useful for environmental managers.However, I felt there was some miscommunication and lack of organization in the way that the class was conducted. TAs would give conflicting and mutually exclusive answers to questions and explanations of work evaluations, for example, and while I was actually more interested in doing a non-Hawaii project, professors should be a bit more careful when using examples from Hawaii research and experience to illustrate course concepts. There were a few times when they referenced very specific events or points of interest related to the Hawaii research by way of illustration - more specific than what we could glean from the Hawaii literature we read. That puts most of the class outside the loop.
group project& trip, inspiring professors
This class is mixing with theories and real practices. This style is very nice to understand theories deeply.
The professors are world experts in Industrial Ecology and they teach the class amazingly.
Class projects gave us an opportunity to apply IE tools to real life situations.
The lectures and professors were great and the material is so interesting. I learned a lot on the group project!

I had a hard time finding a best thing about this course. It was a cursory overview of industrial ecology without much substance. Lectures and course material were somewhat intuitive--basically, I took the class to fill a bin, and didn't get too much out of it.
The project was helpful.

The course is good for first year students who have less experience in industrial ecology. As a 2nd-year, 2nd-semester student who had taken a few courses related to this (linkages, energy, etc), some of it was review.
The field trip to Hawaii, of course.
The trip to Hawaii is awesome. I learned a lot interview skill and built connections with local people.
Industrial ecology is a very interesting field.
Lectures were nice
The Ecomaine trip. We learned first hand from people at a waste to energy plant.
The projects were a chance to explore something new, dig into an area of important beneficial research, and really explore the implications of an area of industrial ecology.
See above
Explaining the limited quantities of materials and how understanding the flow of materials in a system can be useful in better managing resources.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Should be a way for students to choose group members for project- a lot of time to be working with people who where randomly put together and don't get along.
It seems like the instructors ran out of material about half way through. It is also pretty rudimentary.
We had better have some Q&A sessions after the debate.
The contents of the course needs to be revised to fit the title of Industrial ecology. I found the course very much general, and think it needs to focus on more on greening industry operations.
The exam...was not necessarily a good reflection of what I learned. Maybe an exam is not even appropriate for a course like this.

The class provides, in my opinion, a pretty superficial overview of an interesting topic. Another thing that frustrated me was the lack of feedback and discussion stemming from debates. We were assigned a debate and after presenting, we went straight into lecture without any time to ask questions or spark into more lively discussion. I think this was a mistake--we would have gotten more out of the exercise if able to actually follow-up on some of the more controversial points.
The lecture was a little bit easy.I think we can learn more from the lecture and assignments if there are more skills involved rather than just concepts.

The homeworks and their grading was not always clear. Making them broader in scope (longer, and covering more IE concepts) would help as would making the questions clearer. If the questions are to be more subjective in nature (thinking critically about a previous question or a concept we've covered in class), the grading must reflect this.Most classes were concentrated on a certain objective, but having both Marian and Tom step back and talk about the whole picture and how each lecture fits into the Industrial-Ecology puzzle would help.

Selecting the right TA.Debating in class was an excellent idea - However, the judges never spoke about their perspective of an issue. In the end, the whole process was more of a grading exercise than a learning experience.
Need more practical assignments.

The instructors need to present with more authority. They have the expertise, but should really demonstrate it. The tone was too casual/elementary at times. Don't be afraid to dive into the deeper concepts and theoretical underpinnings. The
The problem sets and final project. This is were student really learn how to do industrial ecology and its applicability.
I think that this course is very broad and tries to touch on a lot and it feels a bit too surface level, but I guess it is just an introduction to industrial ecology.

The projects need more structure and clear boundaries such that they can be adequately completed in a semester. This ultimate direction and clear project scope should come from the professors/TAs who have experience with the projects they assign.
See above

I found the course too theoretical while the project was entirely practical. I thought the lectures did not really prepare use to do the project. I would place more emphasis in lecture in explaining how industrial ecology is practiced and how it is useful. Try to cover real problems and real solutions. Try to convey real tools that students can apply in work.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: excellent
Very nice.
I usually contacted the TA. She was always very helpful.
Instructors are great and were available. I didn't checked with TA's that often.
Very available.
They were helpful and accessible.
The TAs were fine. And I found it difficult to get a hold of professors. It seemed if we weren't on a Hawaii trip, our projects were less of a priority.

BinBin was very engaging, and performed well in terms of helping us with the course. Xiaoyue Du, on the other hand was the exact opposite - she was stuck with her point of view and would not consider views from other people. Also, she did not interact very much with everyone in class.
The TAs are super helpful.
The instructors were extremely supportive and responsive. However, they would often only give simplistic answers to questions from the class. Makes them seem unprepared.
So so. They could have been much more proactive helping students with the projects
They were all available and helpful.
See above

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Yes.

The reason I took this course was that I will learn some Green Chemical engineering or about Integrated Chemical Management at policy level, which the course needs to focus on. Again, at the end of the day, the course doesn't given you specific skills in Industrial ecology, but is more based on general concepts.
I took the course to fill a bin.
Since our Hawaii program is long term research, could you keep us for the following progress?
I would like to focus on industrial ecology while I am here.
The course fits very well. However, because of how superficial it is, i think i would have learned just as much from auditing it.
I took this course because I needed it for a bin. It does not really fit into my program all that well.

As I mentioned, Industrial Ecology concepts are very useful in the field of environmental management, in my opinion. I think it provides a useful framework for analysis and also allows us to get some positive hands-on experience.
It doesn't really.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because Industrial Ecology is something FES is famous for and a leader in, also it is not in my usual areas of study and I wanted to learn new tools& perspectives
The Bins.
I want to understand recycle isseus more deeply.
I wanted to know how Industrial operations from engineering perspective which can help in reducing waste which has significant environmental impacts.
It doesn't really necessarily fit perfectly for me, but I was very interested in exploring IE and it was great.
To fill a bin.
Because I did not know anything about industrial ecology.
I heard it is a good class and I really liked it after auditing for two lectures.
Travel to Hawaii.Fits well with my career background and future focus.
I wanted to learn about industrial ecology and its application
I took it to fulfill a bin requirement. I wish the bins would go away.
Industrial ecology is particularly interesting to me. It is a technical class with interesting non-technical aspects.
See above - I like the concepts of IE and I think it provides a useful backdrop for my research and course of study.
I thought that I would obtain tangible skills for evaluating sustainability issues.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes, but I was a little disappointed with inattention to LCA this semester
I didn't really have any to begin with.
Yes.
Yes
Not very much, it was ok.
Yes.

It was too superficial, and I felt like lectures were often a waste of time. The lectures seemed too introductory while the readings seemed more advanced, and I thought it would have been useful to draw the readings into the class a bit more--they were hardly ever discussed, so after the mid-term I did not complete another reading.
I learned so much about this new field, and hope to build my career upon what I learned and experienced from this class.
Yes
Yes.
Too many issues but less focused. Maybe the class materials can include more real case study.
Not quite. Needs refinement.
NO. I learned general concepts, but i did not learn how to do industrial ecology.
I did not know what to expect, but I believe it performed the way I would have envisioned.

Yes. The in-class material could have been more engaging, and further direction on the debates could have been given (on the whole, the debates were relatively weak. The only solution I can think of to this is to provide additional direction and expectations for the debate). That said, in more than 15 years of formal schooling, this is the best class I've ever taken.
Yes, for the most part.
I got a good idea of what industrial ecology has to offer, but I was a little disappointed. I think the course material can be explained more clearly and the course can be made more practical.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I didn't know what to expect.
Yes.
Yes.

I wasn't sure of what to expect--Yale being the center of IE, I thought it would be interesting. But the course material seems intuitive, and I maybe I learned some of the IE lingo, but that's all about all I really took from the course.
Yes.
No
Yes.
no
I got out a lot because we worked hard on our project.
Yes.
See above.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: groups have the potential to teach a lot more than individual work. For this course scheduling meeting times was a major problem, and not all groups got along well
I learned from the other students and I got lucky. I worked with a group of students who were all good workers.
I could expand my knowledge through collaboration with others.

I think the group work was a good learning experience. We worked on Municipal Solid Waste Management in two cities of India, which was very helpful in knowing more about municipal solid waste management.
Everyone brought a different background and knowledge set to the group, which was very helpful for our group project.

Advantages were that the projects were very cool and interesting. Disadvantages were that there were SUCH different requirements for each group in reality...and it was hard to figure out what all was expected sometimes.

This group project was one of the more frustrating things I have ever done. I suppose it provided an appropriate real world experience in dealing and working with people who are probably the last people you would ever choose to work with. I was frustrated and towards the end, I had had it with my project--I just wanted it to end and didn't even care how it ended. I also felt like it was difficult to coordinate with our professor and TA contact; our project contact, however, was extremely helpful and involved.
We could exchange ideas and interpretations about the results.
I learned a lot from my group mates.I hope we can get more instruction before and after our interviewing.
Advantages - Great forum to bounce ideas.- team members keep you motivated.- Work load reduces considerably.Disadvantages - Time consuming, difficult to match everyone's timing.
I learned a lot from my team members.
Sometimes group members are just difficult to get a long with.
Advantanges, i was able to share time with people from other cultures. Disadvantages, because we did not know very well what we were doing it was frustrating at times.

I really want to stress that people had different expectations for the group project and some people did very little work. I was quite disappointed in that aspect. I think our project went well, but it took huge efforts from two people, while one person did not do anything.

Group work made the class interesting and possible. It was nice to get to know a group well, and I believe we worked well together. That said, the groups could have been diversified to minimize weaknesses (for example, mixing groups up so that no group was 100% international students or no group was 100% environmental sciences undergraduates, etc.).

Always tough to schedule and more time-consuming that independent work. That said, I don't think we would be able to accomplish projects on the scale that we do in IE if we were working on our own. I had a very positive group work experience this time around.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it if you have to or are specifically interested in Industrial ecologybut otherwise you can learn all the material elsewhere.
If they can, they should go to Hawaii!
If you want a really superficial overview of Industrial Ecology, take the course.

The course is good for first year students who have less experience in industrial ecology. As a 2nd-year, 2nd-semester student who had taken a few courses related to this (linkages, energy, etc), some of it was review.As a 2nd year, going to Hawaii is very hard with Master's Projects and Theses to deal with, however I hear it's a great trip and if you're interested, you should definitely try to get out there.
Great course; choose your projects carefully.
Ask lots of questions, and follow up if the answer is confusing.
I'm not sure. Will the course is very promising and the instructors are very good, it needs a lot of improvement.
I would take this course if you're interested in Industrial Ecology.

Start in early on the group project. They take time to complete. Also, don't be too drawn in by the Hawaii trip if that's not really your area of interest. I had a very good experience with a non-Hawaii project.
Take it if you are interested in industrial ecology and will make it your primary focus at FES.
